conclusion: Shadows are cast when light is blocked by an object, and their length and position depend on the position of the light source relative to the object.
When the light source moves backwards (away from the objects), the shadows will change in both length and position.
As the light source moves away, the shadows will become longer because the angle of the light rays changes, causing the shadow to stretch out more.

For objects on the left side of the light source (like the birdcage and the pencil), the shadows will move to the right. For objects on the right side (like the lamp and the cross), the shadows will move to the left.

If the light source moves directly away along the line of sight, the shadows will primarily lengthen without significant lateral movement. If it moves at an angle, the shadows will show both elongation and lateral displacement.
The shadow of the birdcage (A) will become longer and shift to the right.
The shadow of the pencil (B) will also lengthen and shift to the right.
The shadow of the lamp (C) will lengthen and shift to the left.
The shadow of the cross (D) will lengthen and shift to the left.
When the light source moves backwards, the shadows A and B will lengthen and shift to the right, while shadows C and D will lengthen and shift to the left.
